Systems Manager allows live troubleshooting through native remote desktop support.

comments.content: Bro I did not find anywhere over the Internet where it speaks about MDM and privacy control, can you share your source?

discussion.content:
Two security benefits of Mobile Device Management (MDM) deployment are:

C. Privacy control checks: MDM solutions often provide features for enforcing privacy controls and compliance policies, which can help protect sensitive user data and ensure that privacy regulations are followed.

E. Robust security policy enforcement: MDM allows organizations to enforce security policies on mobile devices, such as password requirements, encryption, remote wipe capabilities, and app whitelisting/blacklisting, which enhances the security posture of the devices and the data they handle.

Options A, B, and D do not directly relate to the security benefits of MDM deployment.

questions.question_text: Which Cisco security solution stops exfiltration using HTTPS?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Data Exfiltration: Cognitive Threat Analytics uses statistical modeling of an organizationâ€™s network to identify anomalous web traffic and pinpoint the exfiltration of sensitive data. CTA recognizes data exfiltration even in HTTPS encoded traffic, without any need to decrypt transferred content.
https://blogs.cisco.com/security/find-advanced-threats-with-cisco-cognitive-threat-analytics

The Cisco security solution that stops exfiltration using HTTPS is A. Cisco CTA (Cisco Cloud Threat Analytics).

Cisco CTA is a cloud-based security solution that provides visibility into network traffic, allowing it to identify and stop threats, including those using HTTPS for exfiltration. By analyzing network traffic patterns, Cisco CTA can detect and alert on anomalies that may indicate a threat, and take action to block malicious traffic.

Selected Answer: A
Cisco Cognitive Analytics

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

questions.question_text: An engineer is deploying Cisco Advanced Malware Protection (AMP) for Endpoints and wants to create a policy that prevents users from executing a file named abc123456789.exe without quarantining that file. What type of Outbreak Control list must the SHA-256 hash value for the file be added to in order to accomplish this?

discussion.content:
The correct answer is D. Blocked Application

When deploying Cisco Advanced Malware Protection (AMP) for Endpoints, an engineer can create policies to prevent users from executing certain files without quarantining them. To do this, the SHA-256 hash value for the file must be added to a Blocked Application list in the AMP for Endpoints policy.

A Blocked Application list is a type of Outbreak Control list that allows an organization to block specific files or applications, and prevent them from executing on endpoint devices. When a file or application is added to this list, it is blocked and cannot be executed, regardless of its reputation or other characteristics. This can be useful for preventing the execution of known malicious files or applications, or for blocking the execution of files or applications that are known to be vulnerable to exploitation.

In this scenario, the SHA-256 hash value for the file named abc123456789.exe must be added to the Blocked Application list in the AMP for Endpoints policy.

it is asking about preventing execution of a specific file, not an application.
The correct answer is A. Advanced Custom Detection, where the engineer can add the SHA-256 hash value of the file named abc123456789.exe to an Advanced Custom Detection list, this will allow the administrator to prevent execution of the specific file and the file will be quarantined.

Selected Answer: D
A blocked applications list is composed of files that you do not want to allow users to
execute "but do not want to quarantine".
https://docs.amp.cisco.com/AMPPrivateCloudConsoleUserGuide-latest.pdf
